oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Correspondence from Sarah Hamilton to John Hamilton, March 6, 1864
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation:
“March 6th /64
Dear husband
Another opportunity having presented itself, I will write you a few lines. Although I have no news; I can write. We are all tolerable well at present; & doing as well as can be expected under the existing circumstances. I was glad to hear from you; Bro Milrner [sic] said he heard from you a few days before he came up; he came up Saturday & is with us tonight but will start early in the morning. I received a letter from Tommie today by flag of truce dated Feb.1st you will please forward the enclosed to him. I suppose you have heard that Cary & Lou are living within the lines. Do not grieve at the loss of property & negroes; I have learned to bear it all paciently [sic] & put my trust in God & look forward to a brighter future. I wish you could be at home in peace; How long! Oh! How long will this unholy war continue? Oh that it would cease so that every weary homesick wanderer could return home again. As I’ve no news to write; I will close. May good angels guard your sleeping & waking hours; & may God’s strong arm be ever around you is the heart felt prayer of your. Devoted Wife S. A. H.
Harriet & Family are all well & send love to Fred & Marsh. Please to forward the enclosed letters to Albert D & Tommie & Selma”
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from Sarah Hamilton to her husband, John Hamilton. She discusees the loss of the property and the slaves. She bemoans: "How long will this unholy war continue?"

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sarah Ann Hamilton and her husband, the Rev. John Bell Hamilton, lived in the Williamsport area of Maury County, Tennessee. In 1861, Hamilton and his adopted son, Thomas Hamilton Willams, entered into the Confederate army. Captain Hamilton raised a company of cavalry which became part of the Second Tennessee Battalion, later part of the First Tennessee Regiment. Williams and Hamilton were stationed in Mississippi, and were in the retreat from Atlanta.
